case_name: Satyendra Nath Dutta and Subhash Mauzumdar v. Ram Narain

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1971.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and order dated 29th September 1970 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Revision No. 364 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 29th September 1970, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Criminal Revision No. 364 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellants Satyendra Nath Dutta and Subhash Mauzumdar tried by Civil and Sessions Judge, Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Satyendra Nath Dutta and Subhash Mauzumdar were tried by the learned Civil and Sessions Judge, Lucknow,

facts.text: Offences in connection with death of Nanhey Lal and injuries to his son Raj Kishore.

anchor.surface_text: for offences in companynection with the death of one Nanhey Lal and injuries to his son, Raj Kishore.

facts.text: Satyendra Nath Dutta charged under section 302 and section 307 read with section 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Satyendra Nath Dutta was charged under section 302 and section 307 read with section 34 while the other appellant

facts.text: Subhash Mauzumdar charged under section 307 and section 302 read with section 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: was charged under section 307 and section 302 read with section 34 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants upon which Ram Narain,

facts.text: Ram Narain, brother of deceased Nanhey Lal, filed revision in Allahabad High Court under section 439 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: upon which Ram Narain, a brother of the deceased Nanhey Lal, filed a revision application in the High Court of Allahabad under section 439, Code- of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: State of U.P. wanted to file appeal against acquittal but could not as record missing.

anchor.surface_text: challenging the order of acquittal. It is said that the State of U.P. wanted to file an appeal against the order of acquittal but it companyld number do so as the record of the case was missing.

facts.text: High Court allowed revision, set aside acquittal, directed retrial by Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the revision application, set aside the order of acquittal and directed that the appellants be redirected by the Sessions Court.

facts.text: Deceased Nanhey Lal running grocery shop at Hewett Road, Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Nanhey Lal was running a grocery shop at Hewett Road, Lucknow.

facts.text: Pan shop of Hari Sharma Shukla short distance away.

anchor.surface_text: A short distance away from his shop was the Pan shop of one Hari Sharma Shukla.

facts.text: On September 4, 1965 at about 11 p.m., Nanhey Lal, Ram Narain, Raj Kishore, Bijay Kishore and Sheetal Prasad having chat.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4, 1965 the deceas-  1  1951 S.C.R. 676.  3  1968 2 S.C.R. 287.  2  1963 3 S.C.R. 412.  4  1970 1 S.C.R. 880. ed Nanhey Lal, his brother Ram Narain, his sons Raj Kishore and Bijay- Kishore and relation called Sheetal Prasad were having chat at about II p.m.

facts.text: Ram Narain sent Raj Kishore to fetch Pan from Hari Sharma's shop.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain sent Raj Kishore to fetch a Pan from Hari Sharmas shop.

facts.text: Subhash gave cane blow to Raj Kishore.

anchor.surface_text: When Raj Kishore went to bring the Pan, the appellant Subhash is alleged to have given a blow with a cane to him.

facts.text: Nanhey Lal went to Pan shop on hearing shouts.

anchor.surface_text: On hearing the shouts of Raj Kishore, Nanhey Lal went to the Pan shop.

facts.text: Satyendra Nath Dutta snatched cane from Subhash.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the appellant Satyendra Nath Dutta snatched the cane from Subhashs hand.

facts.text: Subhash caught hold of Nanhey Lal facilitating knife attack by Satyendra Nath.

anchor.surface_text: When Nanhey Lal tried to disarm Satyendra Nath Dutta, Subhash is alleged to have caught hold of Nanhey Lal facilitating a knife attack by Satyendra Nath on Nanhey Lal.

facts.text: Raj Kishore intervened, Subhash gave him two knife blows.

anchor.surface_text: Raj Kishore intervened to save his father but Subhash is alleged to have given him two knife blows.

facts.text: Nanhey Lal succumbed to injuries at about 5 a.m. next morning.

anchor.surface_text: At about 5 a.m. the next morning Nanhey Lal succumbed to, his injuries.

facts.text: Prosecution examined five eye-witnesses: Ram Narain, Barati Lal, Bijay Kishore, Kallu and Raj Kishore.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution examined five eye-witnesses, Ram Narain, Barati Lal, Bijay Kishore, Kallu and Raj Kishore.

facts.text: Cycle taken on hire by Subhash found at scene of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution also relied on the circumstance that a cycle taken on hire by Subhash was found at the scene of occurrence.

facts.text: Raj Kishore made statement at Balrampur Hospital at 2:30 p.m. on September 5, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Raj Kishore who was also injured during the incident had made a dying declaration at the Balrampur Hospital, Lucknow, at about 2- 30 p.m. on September 5.

facts.text: First Information Report lodged without delay mentioning Ram Narain and Bijay Kishore as eye-witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: He also referred to what clearly was an important, circumstance that the First Information Report, which was lodged without delay, mentioned the names of Ram Narain and Bijay Kishore as eye-witnesses.

facts.text: Sessions Judge rejected evidence of eye-witnesses for various reasons.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judge found the evidence of these and other eye-wit- nesses unacceptable for a variety of reasons.

facts.text: No identification parade held.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the Sessions Court companycluded that numbere of the eye- witnesses knew the appellants and therefore the Investigating Officer ought to have held an identification parade.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order directing retrial.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has thus transgressed the narrow limits of its revisional jurisdiction under section 439 4  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

concepts.interpretation: Revisional powers of High Court, limited against acquittal especially by private complainant; cannot convert acquittal to conviction per sub-s(4); exercised only in exceptional cases like manifest illegality or gross miscarriage of justice

issues.text: Whether the High Court transgressed the narrow limits of its revisional jurisdiction under section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure by setting aside the acquittal and directing retrial

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has thus transgressed the narrow limits of its revisional jurisdiction under section 439 4  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The judgment of the Sessions Court did number suffer from any manifest illegality and the interests of justice did number require the High Court to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions, Court. Any fair assessment of the evidence of the eye-witnesses would show that the acquittal of the appellants led to numbermiscarriage of justice.

issues.text: Whether the revisional jurisdiction under section 439 CrPC ought to be exercised by a private complainant against an order of acquittal which the State could have appealed under section 417

anchor.surface_text: In D. Stephens v. Nosibolla 1  it was held by this Court that the revisional jurisdiction conferred by section 439 of the Code ought number to be exercised lightly when it is invoked by a private complainant against an order of acquittal which could have been appealed against by the Government under section 417. It would be exercised only in exceptional cases where the interests of public justice require interference for the correction of a manifest illegality, or the prevention of a gross miscarriage of justice.

issues.text: Whether the High Court could direct retrial in revision against acquittal based on re-appraisal of evidence without converting the acquittal to conviction

anchor.surface_text: In Logendranath jha Others v. Polailal Biswas 1  the High Court, at the instance of private complainant, set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court and directed that the accused be retried. This Court held that the provision contained in section 439 4  of the Code cannot be construed to mean that in dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal the High Court could, in the absence of any error on a point of law, reappraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts,provided only it stops short of finding the accused guilty and passing sentence on him.

issues.text: Whether failure of the Investigating Officer to hold identification parade entitles the accused to benefit where eye-witnesses claimed to know the appellants

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the Sessions Court concluded that none of the eye- witnesses knew the appellants and therefore the Investigating Officer ought to have held an identification parade. In the absence of the parade the claim of the witnesses that they could identify the appellants was difficult to test. The High Court dismissed the last ground that no identification parade was held by saying that the appellants did not ask for an identification parade and therefore the benefit of that omission could not go to them.

issues.text: Whether the Sessions Court's conclusion that Nanhey Lal's dying declaration was recorded and suppressed justified setting aside the acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the acquittal principally on the ground that the learned Sessions Judge was in error in holding that the dying declaration of Nanhey Lal was also recorded but that it was suppressed by the prosecution. According to the High Court the finding that Nanhey Lals dying declaration was recorded is not based on any legally admissible evidence but wholly on inadmissible evidence. ... That conclusion may be wrong but that cannot justify setting aside the order of acquittal and directing a re-trial of the appellants.

arguments.claim: Revisional jurisdiction under section 439 CrPC conferred on High Court ought not to be exercised lightly when invoked by private complainant against acquittal appealable by State under s.417

anchor.surface_text: This provision has been judicially interpreted and it is necessary to refer to the decision of this Court bearing on the construction thereof. In D. Stephens v. Nosibolla 1 it was held by this Court that the revisional jurisdiction conferred by section 439 of the Code ought not to be exercised lightly when it is invoked by a private complainant against an order

arguments.claim: Revisional jurisdiction exercised only in exceptional cases for correction of manifest illegality or prevention of gross miscarriage of justice

anchor.surface_text: It would be exercised only in exceptional cases where the interests of public justice require interference for the correction of a manifest illegality, or the prevention of a gross miscarriage of justice. In other words, the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court cannot be invoked merely because the lower court has taken a wrong

anchor.surface_text: By an elaborate process of reasoning the High Court found that the eyewitnesses knew the appellants and therefore in any case it was unnecessary to hold an identification parade.

arguments.claim: Nanhey Lal made dying declaration which was recorded but suppressed by prosecution

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judge found the evidence of these and other eye-wit- nesses unacceptable for a variety of reasons. Raj Kishore who was also injured during the incident had made a dying declaration at the Balrampur Hospital, Lucknow, at about 2- 30 p.m. on September 5.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ld by examining a few aspects of the evidence that the accused were previously known to the eye-witnesses and thirdly it assumed wrongly that the comp

arguments.court_reasoning: SC agrees with HC that Sessions wrong, based on inadmissible evidence like IO's remand note contradicted

arguments.claim: Eye-witness evidence unreliable: Raj Kishore's hospital statement omits Ram Narain despite explaining relation; inconsistent with Sheetal Prasad mention

anchor.surface_text: The statement made by Raj Kishore could not be treated as a dying declaration because he survived the attack. But he was cross-examined in reference to that statement and he explained his omission to refer to Ram Narains presence by saying that since Ram Narain was a close relation

arguments.claim: Ram Narain, elder brother, did not take injured to hospital; young Bijay Kishore did

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain was the elder brother of the deceased and yet he did not remove either the deceased or Raj Kishore to the hospitals They were removed to the hospital by Bijay Kishore, hardly 12 or 13 years of age.

arguments.claim: Bijay Kishore's presence not mentioned by Ram Narain in FIR or committing court; explanation rejected; omitted in Raj's declaration

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the evidence of Bijay Kishore, though Ram Narain had mentioned the names of eye-witnesses in the First Information Report he did not mention the name of Bijay Kishore. In fact, Ram Narain did not refer to Bijay Kishores presence even in the committing Court.

arguments.claim: Barati Lal chance witness with unnatural conduct; claim of immediate statement recording belied

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the other witnesses was also rejected by the Sessions Court. Barati Lal was a chance witness. His conduct in not talking to anyone at the spot was unnatural and his claim that his statement was recorded by the Investigating Officer the same night

arguments.claim: Kallu unreliable as rickshaw puller frequently testifying for police

anchor.surface_text: Kallu is a rickshaw puller and he appeared to be at the beck and call of the police. He had given evidence in three or four police cases.

arguments.claim: Raj Kishore's cane blow uncorroborated by medical exam soon after

anchor.surface_text: In regard to Raj Kishore the Sessions Court referred to the contradiction between the, statement he made in the hospital and the case of the prosecution bearing on the sequence of events. Raj Kishores evidence that he was given a cane blow

arguments.claim: Bicycle recovery not incriminating as from wrong location (Bengali Sweet House, not Pan shop)

anchor.surface_text: The recovery of the bicycle which was relied upon by the prosecution as connecting the appellant Subhash with the crime was discarded by the Sessions Court as an incriminating circumstance as it was recovered not from near Hari Sharmas Pan shop

arguments.claim: High Court cannot re-appreciate eye-witness evidence in revision

anchor.surface_text: Being aware of the limitations or the powers of a revisional court the High Court perhaps did not consider the reasons which influenced the Sessions Court in discarding the evidence of the eyewitnesses. In doing so the High Court was right

arguments.claim: Sessions acquittal mainly based on unreliability of eye-witnesses, not dying declaration suppression

anchor.surface_text: But the judgment of the Sessions Court is not based on the suppression of Nanhey Lals dying declaration The Sessions Judge examined the evidence of the eye-witnesses critically and came to the conclusion that it was unsafe to act on that evidence.

holdings.text: The High Court transgressed the narrow limits of its revisional jurisdiction under section 439(4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure by setting aside the order of acquittal and directing retrial.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has thus transgressed the narrow limits of its revisional jurisdiction under section 439 4  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The judgment of the Sessions Court did number suffer from any manifest illegality and the interests of justice did number require the High Court to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions, Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reappraised evidence, blamed accused for not demanding ID parade, wrongly focused on minor dying declaration issue while ignoring main basis of acquittal (eye-witness unreliability); applied precedents limiting revision to exceptional cases of manifest illegality or miscarriage of justice.

holdings.text: Revisional jurisdiction under section 439 CrPC ought not to be exercised lightly when invoked by a private complainant against an order of acquittal appealable by the State under section 417.

anchor.surface_text: This provision has been judicially interpreted and it is necessary to refer to the decision of this Court bearing on the construction thereof. In D. Stephens v. Nosibolla 1 it was held by this Court that the revisional jurisdiction conferred by section 439 of the Code ought not to be exercised lightly when it is invoked by a private complainant against an order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed D. Stephens v. Nosibolla: exercised only in exceptional cases for manifest illegality or gross miscarriage of justice; not merely wrong view of law or misappreciation of evidence.

holdings.text: High Court cannot, in revision by private party against acquittal, reappraise evidence and reverse findings of fact even if stopping short of conviction, as that is formal compliance with s.439(4).

anchor.surface_text: In Logendranath Jha Others v. Polailal Biswas 1 the High Court, at the instance of private complainant, set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court and directed that the accused be retried. This Court held that the provision contained in section 439 4 of the Code cannot be construed to mean that

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Logendranath Jha: such retrial order based on evidence reappraisal circumvents prohibition on converting acquittal to conviction.

holdings.text: Revisional jurisdiction exercised only in exceptional cases: glaring defect in procedure, manifest error of law, flagrant miscarriage of justice (e.g., lack of jurisdiction, excluding admissible evidence, overlooking material evidence).

anchor.surface_text: In K. Chinnaswamy Reddy V. State of Andhra Pradesh 2 the Court while emphasising that the revisional jurisdiction should be exercised by the High Court in exceptional cases only when there is some glaring defect in the procedure or a manifest error on a point of law resulting in a flagrant miscarriage

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed K. Chinnaswamy Reddy: illustrated categories justifying interference; no such exceptional circumstances here.

holdings.text: High Court wrong to enter into minute details of evidence in revision against acquittal at instance of private party.

anchor.surface_text: In Mahendra Pratap Singh v. Sarju Singh Anr. 3 where the High Court in exercise of its revisional powers had, at the instance of a private party, directed re-trial of the accused, this Court on a review of the previous decisions reaffirmed that the High Court was wrong in entering into minute details

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Mahendra Pratap Singh: reaffirmed limits on detailed evidence scrutiny in revision.

holdings.text: High Court cannot set aside acquittal merely because it disbelieves eye-witnesses without sifting grain from chaff; that constitutes impermissible re-appraisal.

anchor.surface_text: The last decision to which reference may be made is Khetrabasi Samal etc. v. State of Orissa etc 4 . The High Court while exercising its revisional jurisdiction had set aside the order of acquittal on the ground that the Magistrate should not have disbelieved the three eye-witnesses. The High Court sought

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Khetrabasi Samal: set aside HC order for reappraising witness credibility.

holdings.text: Sessions Court's judgment did not suffer from manifest illegality; interests of justice did not require interference; acquittal led to no miscarriage of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Sessions Court did number suffer from any manifest illegality and the interests of justice did number require the High Court to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions, Court. Any fair assessment of the evidence of the eye-witnesses would show that the acquittal of the appellants led to numbermiscarriage of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No glaring defects or errors; eye-witness evidence fairly assessed as unreliable by Sessions Court.

holdings.text: Error to blame accused for not demanding identification parade; Investigating Officer ought to hold it where witnesses claim prior knowledge of accused.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions Court rightly noted absence made identification claim hard to test; HC wrongly shifted burden to accused.

holdings.text: Even if Sessions Court erred on dying declaration suppression (based on inadmissible evidence), that does not justify setting aside acquittal as main basis was eye-witness unreliability.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquittal dominantly rested on critical examination of eye-witnesses; minor error insufficient for revision.

anchor.surface_text: In D. Stephens v. Nosibolla 1 it was held by this Court that the revisional jurisdiction conferred by section 439 of the Code ought not to be exercised lightly when it is invoked by a private complainant against an order of acquittal which could have been appealed against by the Government under section 417.

precedents.cited_proposition: revisional jurisdiction conferred by section 439 ought not to be exercised lightly when invoked by private complainant against acquittal appealable by Government under s.417; only in exceptional cases for correction of manifest illegality or prevention of gross miscarriage of justice; not merely for wrong view of law or misappreciation of evidence

precedents.citation: Logendranath jha Others v. Polailal Biswas 1

anchor.surface_text: In Logendranath jha Others v. Polailal Biswas 1 the High Court, at the instance of private complainant, set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court and directed that the accused be retried. This Court held that the provision contained in section 439(4) of the Code cannot be construed to mean that in dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal the High Court could, in the absence of any error on a point of law, reappraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts, provided only it stops short of finding the accused guilty and passing sentence on him.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.439(4) does not permit High Court in private party's revision against acquittal to reappraise evidence and reverse fact findings short of conviction; retrial order based on such re-appraisal is invalid formal compliance

precedents.citation: K. Chinnaswamy reddy V. State of Andhra Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: In K. Chinnaswamy reddy V. State of Andhra Pradesh 2 the Court while emphasising that the revisional jurisdiction should be exercised by the High Court in exceptional cases only when there is some glaring defect in the procedure or a manifest error on a point of law resulting in a flagrant miscarriage of justice observed that it was not possible to lay down the criteria for determining such exceptional cases which would cover all contingencies.

precedents.case_name: K. Chinnaswamy Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: revisional jurisdiction exercised only in exceptional cases like glaring procedural defect or manifest legal error causing flagrant miscarriage; illustrations: court lacking jurisdiction, excluding admissible evidence, relying on inadmissible, overlooking material evidence

precedents.citation: Mahendra Pratap Singh v. Sarju Singh Anr.  3

anchor.surface_text: In Mahendra Pratap Singh v. Sarju Singh Anr.  3 where the High Court in exercise of its revisional powers had, at the instance of a private party, directed re-trial of the accused, this Court on a review of the previous decisions reaffirmed that the High Court was wrong in entering into minute details of evidence, while examining the decision of the Sessions Court under section 439(4) of the Code.

precedents.case_name: Mahendra Pratap Singh v. Sarju Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: in revision under s.439(4) against acquittal at private instance, High Court should not enter into minute details of evidence

precedents.citation: Khetrabasi Samal etc. v. State of Orissa etc 4

anchor.surface_text: The last decision to which reference may be made is Khetrabasi Samal etc. v. State of Orissa etc 4 . The High Court while exercising its revisional jurisdiction had set aside the order of acquittal on the ground that the Magistrate should not have disbelieved the three eye-witnesses. The High Court sought justification for the course it adopted by observing that the Magistrate had not taken the trouble of sifting the grain from the chaff. The order of the High Court was set aside by this Court.

precedents.case_name: Khetrabasi Samal v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court erred in setting aside acquittal in revision by holding magistrate should not disbelieve eye-witnesses and failed to sift evidence properly; such order set aside
